title: NRL 2020 draw Melbourne Storm home games
text:
NRL: CEO Todd Greenberg has announced the draw for the 2020 season.

Melbourne Storm has been rewarded for its sustained success, given a number of home blockbusters next season, but the minor premier must first navigate a taxing early schedule.

Storm is one of four clubs allotted three five-day turnarounds, including one before its Round 6 assignment in Townsville.

Storm chief executive Dave Donaghy backed his football department to overcome the tough early-season block.

“Our challenge now is when the footy department come back in mid-November to work their way through that,” Donaghy said.

“The planning and what’s going to be needed to step our way through that period.

“Flip side of that is the back end of the year is pretty consistent in terms of turnarounds and no five-day turnarounds.”

Rugby League Players’ Association stakeholder relations manager Clint Newton welcomed the 2020 draw but said “player welfare” must always be paramount.

The NRL has reduced the number of five-day breaks from 26 in 2019 to 25 next year.

“While we ideally want to reduce the amount of five-day turnarounds,” Newton said.

“It is also important to reduce the issues associated with these events such as travel either side and the length of time between each occurrence for clubs affected more than once.

“We are generally pleased with the reduction of substantial travel either side of the five-day turnarounds … with one team (Storm) set to be impacted compared with three in 2019.”

As revealed by the Herald Sun, Craig Bellamy’s team will start the season with back-to-back away games before its Round 3 clash with Penrith Panthers at AAMI Park.

The club’s fixture haul include:

– 14 matches free-to-air matches.

– Three Friday night matches in Melbourne against West Tigers (R16), Cronulla Sharks (R19) and Sydney Roosters (R23).

– A Thursday night showdown with Souths Sydney in Round 4

– The Anzac night blockbuster against New Zealand at AAMI Park.

– Three of the last five matches will also be in Melbourne.

Storm had hoped to host the season-opener and capitalise on there not being any AFL in Melbourne on the weekend of March 15.

While the request was denied, the club will host Brisbane in Round 24 – the penultimate round of the NRL season – to benefit from the AFL’s pre-finals bye.

Storm chief executive Dave Donaghy welcomed the NRL’s 2020 home-and-away fixture.

“That (Broncos game) is certainly one for people to circle in their calendars,” Donaghy said.

“There is a number of blockbusters we have got locked in for our members and fans next year.”
